https://prez.dev/description.@value: Compilation of terms that describe the classification of alteration in a rock, with a focus on hydrothermal processes (i.e. mineralogical, chemical and textural changes resulting from the interaction of hot aqueous fluids with the rocks through which they circulate, under evolving physico-chemical conditions), and excluding weathering, mineralization and direct metamorphic or magmatic processes. Classification is based on the identification of the most important alteration mineral, the distinctive mineral assemblage, or the chemical changes that have occurred during alteration. Definitions are largely from Pirajno (2009), the Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et.al., 2011), Thompson et al. (1996), and Wikipedia.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The alteration of pure limestone and dolomite by introduction of Si, Al, Fe and Mg. Typical skarn minerals include pyroxene, garnet, vesuvianite, wollastonite, actinolite, magnetite or hematite, epidote and scapolite.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: Einaudi, MT, Meinert, LD and Newberry, RJ 1981, Skarn deposits, in 75th anniversary volume: 1906–1980 (1st edition) edited by B Skinner: Economic Geology Publishing Company, Littleton, Colorado, USA, p. 317–391, doi:10.5382/AV75.11.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: The alteration of pure limestone and dolomite by introduction of Si, Al, Fe and Mg. Typical skarn minerals include pyroxene, garnet, vesuvianite, wollastonite, actinolite, magnetite or hematite, epidote and scapolite.

Generally forms replacement zones in wallrocks (exoskarn - in limestone or occasionally mafic to intermediate volcanic rocks), or within intrusions (endoskarn). Andradite and diopside occur in oxidized assemblages related to porphyry Cu systems; grossular and hedenbergite are more common in reduced skarns (Au, W, and Sn).

Metasomatic replacement of dolomitic limestone. High-temperature magnesian skarns are characterized by forsterite and diopside and low-temperature magnesian skarns contain serpentinite and talc. Both occur as retrograde minerals after forsterite and clinopyroxene.

The overprinting of earlier (prograde) skarn alteration in the form of epidote, amphibole, chlorite, and other hydrous phases. It is typically structurally controlled and more pronounced in shallow environments; but may also affect adjacent wallrock limestone.
